original_data.question: A 3-month-old infant is brought to her pediatrician because she coughs and seems to have difficulty breathing while feeding. In addition, she seems to have less energy compared to other babies and appears listless throughout the day. She was born by cesarean section to a G1P1 woman with no prior medical history and had a normal APGAR score at birth. Her parents say that she has never been observed to turn blue. Physical exam reveals a high-pitched holosystolic murmur that is best heard at the lower left sternal border. The most likely cause of this patient's symptoms is associated with which of the following abnormalities?

model_response:
The infant has a common form of congenital heart disease, a ventricular septal defect (VSD). The defect is characterized by a holosystolic murmur, which is best heard at the left lower sternal border. The murmur is caused by the abnormal flow of blood from the left ventricle to the right ventricle. The American Heart Association estimates that VSD is the most common congenital heart defect, accounting for 40% of all cases. The defect is more common in females than in males. The incidence of VSD is increased in infants whose mothers have been exposed to lithium during pregnancy. The 22q11 deletion syndrome is also associated with VSD. The other conditions listed are not associated with VSD.

Answer: OPTION C IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: A child between 1 and 23 months of age.
A medical doctor with specialized training in the care of children.

A sudden, audible expulsion of air from the lungs through a partially closed glottis, preceded by inhalation. It is a protective response that serves to clear the trachea, bronchi, and/or lungs of irritants and secretions, or to prevent aspiration of foreign materials into the lungs.
Difficult or labored breathing.
A child between 1 and 23 months of age.
Lack of emotion or emotional expression; a disorder of motivation that persists over time.
Occurring or done each day.
The event of being born.
Extraction of the FETUS by means of abdominal HYSTEROTOMY.
This gene plays a role in the metabolism of double-stranded RNA.
Human females as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
A record of a patient's background regarding health and the occurrence of disease events of the individual. In addition, personal medical history may be a variable in epidemiologic studies.
The process of giving birth to one or more offspring.
Persons functioning as natural, adoptive, or substitute parents. The heading includes the concept of parenthood as well as preparation for becoming a parent.

The hue of that portion of the visible spectrum lying between green and indigo, evoked in the human observer by radiant energy with wavelengths of approximately 420 to 490 nanometers; any of a group of colors that may vary in lightness and saturation, whose hue is that of a clear daytime sky.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
Period of contraction of the HEART, especially of the HEART VENTRICLES.

Heart sounds caused by vibrations resulting from the flow of blood through the heart. Heart murmurs can be examined by HEART AUSCULTATION, and analyzed by their intensity (6 grades), duration, timing (systolic, diastolic, or continuous), location, transmission, and quality (musical, vibratory, blowing, etc).
A condition in which a person partially loses the ability to hear sounds in one or both ears.
The location of the chest pain is along the left lower border of the sternum.

Fundamental claims of patients, as expressed in statutes, declarations, or generally accepted moral principles. (Bioethics Thesaurus) The term is used for discussions of patient rights as a group of many rights, as in a hospital's posting of a list of patient rights.
Joined in some kind of relationship.
Malformations of organs or body parts during development in utero.
